etymology.description: Differentiated form of 高 (“high, tall”), marked with an added element—variously a stroke, 屮, 止, 力, 九, or 夭; later Shuowen misread the 夭 form and treated it as phono-semantic.
etymology.interpretation: Originally a marked variant of 高 used to indicate the idea of height/loftiness while distinguishing it graphically with small markers. The 夭-shaped variant became standard in later scripts, which led some scholars to mistakenly analyze 夭 as a semantic component and reclassify it.
etymology.simplification: Simplified to 乔 by generalizing the later 夭-based outline and removing the complex 高 framework, reducing strokes and regularizing the shape in the PRC simplification scheme.

examples.chinese: 庭院里种着几株乔木(庭院裡種著幾株喬木)。
examples.pinyin: Tíngyuàn lǐ zhòng zhe jǐ zhū qiáomù.
examples.english: Several tall trees are planted in the courtyard.

examples.chinese: 他搬新家，亲友前来道贺，祝他乔迁之喜(他搬新家，親友前來道賀，祝他喬遷之喜)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bān xīnjiā, qīnyǒu qiánlái dàohè, zhù tā qiáoqiān zhī xǐ.
examples.english: He moved to a new home, and friends and relatives came to congratulate him, wishing him joy on his relocation.

examples.chinese: 此地乔木参天(此地喬木參天)。
examples.english: The tall trees here reach to the sky.
